author: R Vimal Kumar
text:
The conference organised by the Confederation of Indian Industry, and NIFT-TEA Knitwear Industry in Tirupur.– Photo: R. VIMAL KUMAR

Lack of systematic studies to understand the reasons for the high rate of attrition in textile clusters including Tirupur, is a cause for concern, according to J. V. Rao, Chief Executive Officer of Textile Sector Skill Council.

“Attrition affects quality of production as well as profitability as new set of people who replace the workers moved out will take time to perform at desired levels,” Mr. Rao told The Hindu.

He was here to attend a conference organised by the Confederation of Indian Industry and NIFT-TEA Knitwear Institute on ‘Performance enhancement towards world class manufacturing.’

The textile units should conduct ‘exit interviews’ when workers move out, and evolve a tracking system to understand whether the workers who left the units were returning after some time.

Mr. Rao was of the opinion that it was imperative for textile businessmen to join hands for a collective growth.“Individual excellences by few units will not do help improve the image of Tirupur in the eyes of foreign buyers,” he said. About 70,000 new employees needed to be inducted in spinning, weaving, knitting, and processing sectors in the country every year for the next few years.

“Units should take responsibility of training them effectively,” he said.

CII (Tirupur district council) chairman M. Velusamy; NIFT-TEA Institute chief mentor Raja Shanmugam; and Tirupur Thozhil Pathukappu Kuzhu coordinator T.R. Vijayakumar; were among those who spoke on various techniques that needed to be adopted for improving apparel production.
title: ‘Reasons for high attrition not studied ’
